title: Understanding SQL Clauses Order
text: In SQL, the order of clauses is important. The typical order is: SELECT, FROM, WHERE, GROUP BY, HAVING, ORDER BY.

hintAnswer: The WHERE clause should come before the ORDER BY clause.
title: Identifying the Error
text: What is wrong with the following query? SELECT City, COUNT(*) FROM Customers ORDER BY City WHERE City LIKE 'New%'
choices: The WHERE clause should come before the ORDER BY clause.
The ORDER BY clause should not use a wildcard.
COUNT should be used with a specific column.
The results should be ordered by customer ID.

title: Using COUNT in SQL
text: The COUNT function is used to return the number of rows that match a specified condition. It can be used with or without a specific column.

hintAnswer: SELECT City (comma) COUNT(*) FROM Customers WHERE City LIKE 'New%' ORDER BY City
title: Correcting the Query
text: Rewrite the query to correct the order of clauses.
